title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Random Force, Part 2, Eipit, who reads true, Stankwist.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Hello, I'm Josh Starmer and welcome to Stankwist.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Today we're doing Random Force Part 2, and we're going to focus on missing data in sample

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: clustering.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: To be honest, the sample clustering aspect of Random Force is my favorite part, so I'm really excited

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: we're going to cover it.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Here's our data set.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: We've got data for four separate patients.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: However, for patient number four, we've got some missing data.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Random forests consider two types of missing data.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: One, missing data in the original dataset used to create the random forest, and two, missing

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: data in a new sample that we want to categorize.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: We'll start with this one.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: So we want to create a random forest from this data.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: However, we don't know if this patient has blocked arteries or their weight.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: The general idea for dealing with missing data in this context is to make an initial guess

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: that could be bad, and then gradually refine the guess until it is hopefully a good guess.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Because this person did not have heart disease, the initial and possibly bad, guess for the

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: blocked arteries value is just the most common value for blocked arteries found in the

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: other samples that do not have heart disease.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Among the people that do not have heart disease, no is the most common value for blocked

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: arteries.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: It occurs in two out of two samples.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: So no is our initial guess.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: This weight is numeric.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Our initial guess will be the median value of the patients that did not have heart disease.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: In this case, the median value is 167.5.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Here's our new dataset with the filled in missing values.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Now we want to refine these guesses.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: We do this by first determining which samples are similar to the one with missing data.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: So let's talk about how to determine similarity.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Step 1.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Build a random forest.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Step 2.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Run all of the data down all of the trees.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: We'll start by running all of the data down the first tree.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Do-vid-u-vid-u-vid-u-vid-u-vid-u-vid-u-vid-u-vid-u-vidä½“.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Notice that sample 3 and sample 4 both ended up at the same leaf node.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: That means they're similar, at least that cell similarity is defined in random forests.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: We keep track of similar samples using a proximity matrix.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: The proximity matrix has a row for each sample, and it has a column for each sample.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Because sample 3 and sample 4 ended up in the same leaf node, we put a 1 here.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: We also put a 1 here, since this position also represents samples 3 and 4.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Because no other pair of samples ended in the same leaf node, our proximity matrix looks

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: like this after running the samples down the first tree.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Now we run all of the data down the second tree.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: No, samples 2, 3 and 4 all ended up in the same leaf node.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: This is what the proximity matrix looked like after running the data down the first tree.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: And after the second tree, we add 1 to any pair of samples that ended up in the same leaf node.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: And samples 3 and 4 ended up in the same node together again.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: And sample 2 also ended up in that same node.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Now we run all of the data down the third tree.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: And here's the updated proximity matrix.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Only samples 3 and 4 ended up in the same leaf node.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Ultimately, we run the data down all the trees and the proximity matrix fills in.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Then we divide each proximity value by the total number of trees.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: In this example, assume we had 10 trees.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Now we use the proximity values for sample 4 to make better guesses about the missing data.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: For blocked arteries, we calculate the weighted frequency of yes and no using proximity values

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: as the weights.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Yes, occurs in one third of the samples.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: The weighted frequency for yes is the frequency of yes times the weight for yes.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: The weight for yes equals the proximity of yes divided by all of the proximity.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: The proximity for yes is the proximity value for sample 2.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: The only one with yes.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: And we divide that by the sum of the number of the number of the proximity values.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: So the weight for yes is 0.1.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Thus, the weighted frequency for yes is 0.03.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: The weighted frequency for no is the frequency of no, which is 2-thirds, times the weight for no.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Samples 1 and 3 both have no.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: With that in mind, we can plug in the values for the proximity of no, divided by all proximity.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Thus, the weight for no is 0.9.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: And we can plug in the values for the proximity of no divided by all proximity.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Thus, the weight for no is 0.9.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: And the weighted frequency for no is 0.6.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: No has a way higher weighted frequency, so we'll go with it.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: In other words, our new improved and revised guests based on the proximity is no for blocked arteries.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: For weight, we use the proximity to calculate a weighted average.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: In this case, the weighted average equals sample 1's weight.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Sample 1's weighted average weight.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Sorry if there's any confusion between a patient's weight or a sample's weight and the weight used in the weighted average.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: To calculate that weight, we start with the proximity for sample 1, divided by the sum of the proximity.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: So sample 1's weighted average weight is 0.1.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Here's the weighted value for sample number 2, who weighs 180.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Here's the weighted average value for sample number 3, who weighs 2.10.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Ultimately, the weighted average of weight is 198.5.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: And remember, the weights that we used in the weighted average were based on proximity.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Now that we've revised our guesses a little bit, we do the whole thing over again.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: We build a random forest, run the data through the trees, recalculate the proximity and recalculate the missing values.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: We do this six or seven times until the missing values converge.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: I.e. no longer change each time we recalculate.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Bam.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Now it's time for an inner loot of awesomeness.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Let me show you something super cool we can do with the proximity matrix.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: This is the proximity matrix before we divided each value by 10, the number of trees in the pretend random forest.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Just for the sake of easy math, imagine if samples 3 and 4 ended up in the same leaf node in all 10 trees.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Now we have a 10 here and here.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: After dividing by 10, the number of trees in the forest, we see that the largest number in the proximity matrix is 1.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: 1 in the proximity matrix means the samples are as close as close can be.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: That means 1 minus the proximity values equals distance.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Closes can be equals no distance between and not close equals far away.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: This is a distance matrix and that means we can draw heat map with it.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: If you don't know what a heat map is, check out the stack quest.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: I think this is super cool because it means that no matter what the data are, ranks, multiple choice, numeric, etc.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: If we can use it to make a tree, we can draw heat map or an MDS plot to show how the samples are related to each other.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: This is awesome.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Dremble, bam.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: I think this is a very good example of a tree.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: I think this is a very good example of a tree.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: I think this is a very good example of a tree.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: I think this is a very good example of a tree.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Dremble, bam.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Okay, enough fun stuff.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Let's get back to the missing data problem.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: At long last, we'll talk about the second method.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: This is when we have missing data in a new sample that we want to categorize.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Imagine we had already built a random forest with existing data and wanted to classify this new patient.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: So we want to know if they have heart disease or not.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: But we don't know if they have blocked arteries.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: So we need to make a guess about blocked arteries so we can run the patient down all the trees in the forest.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: The first thing we do is create two copies of the data.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: One that has heart disease and one that doesn't have heart disease.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Then we use the iterative method we just talked about to make a good guess about the missing values.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: These are the guesses that we came up with.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Then we run the two samples down the trees in the forest.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: And we see which of the two is correctly labeled by the random forest the most times.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: This option was correctly labeled yes in all three trees.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: This option was only correctly labeled no in one tree.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: This option wins because it was correctly labeled more than the other option.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Bam.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: We filled in the missing data and we've classified our sample.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests Part 2: Missing data and clustering
text: Hey, we've made it to the end of another exciting stat quest.
